rev.comment: None of these music samples are referenced in the article, total fail of [[WP:NFCC]] #8
rev.diff:
Line 27: Line 27:
===Origins: 1980s===
===Origins: 1980s===
â
{{Listen
+
Emo emerged from the [[hardcore punk]] scene of early-1980s [[Washington, D.C.]], both as a reaction to the increased violence within the scene and as an extension of the personal politics espoused by [[Ian MacKaye]] of [[Minor Threat]], who had turned the focus of the music from the community back towards the individual.<ref name="Greenwald, 12">{{cite book|last =Greenwald|first =Andy|authorlink =Andy Greenwald|title =[[Nothing Feels Good: Punk Rock, Teenagers, and Emo]]|publisher =[[St. Martin's Griffin]]|date =2003|location =[[New York City|New York]]|isbn =0-312-30863-9|page=9â11}}</ref><ref name="Blush, 157">{{cite book|last = Blush|first = Steven|authorlink = Steven Blush|title = [[American Hardcore: A Tribal History]]|publisher = [[Feral House]]|date = 2001|location = [[New York City|New York]]|isbn = 0-922925-71-7|page=157}}</ref> Minor Threat fan [[Guy Picciotto]] formed [[Rites of Spring]] in 1984, breaking free of hardcore's self-imposed boundaries in favor of melodic guitars, varied rhythms, and deeply personal, impassioned lyrics.<ref>Greenwald, p. 12.</ref> Many of the band's themes would become familiar tropes in later generations of emo music, including nostalgia, romantic bitterness, and poetic desperation.<ref>Greenwald, pp. 12â13.</ref> Their performances became public emotional purges where audience members would sometimes weep.<ref>Greenwald, p. 13.</ref> MacKaye became a huge Rites of Spring fan, recording their only album and serving as their roadie on tour, and soon formed a new band of his own called [[Embrace (American band)|Embrace]] which explored similar themes of self-searching and emotional release.<ref name="Greenwald, 14">Greenwald, p. 14.</ref> Similar bands soon followed in connection with the "Revolution Summer" of 1985, a deliberate attempt by members of the Washington, D.C. scene to break from the rigid constraints of hardcore in favor of a renewed spirit of creativity.<ref name="Blush, 157"/> Bands such as [[Gray Matter (band)|Gray Matter]], [[Beefeater (band)|Beefeater]], [[Fire Party]], [[Dag Nasty]], Lunchmeat, and Kingface were connected to this movement.<ref name="Blush, 157"/><ref name="Greenwald, 14"/>
â
|filename = Rites of Spring - Remainder.ogg
  â
|title = "Remainder" by Rites of Spring
  â
|description = The melodic guitars, varied rhythms, and deeply personal lyrics of [[Rites of Spring]] broke from the rigid boundaries of [[hardcore punk|hardcore]] and helped launch the "emotional hardcore" or "emocore" style.
  â
}}Emo emerged from the [[hardcore punk]] scene of early-1980s [[Washington, D.C.]], both as a reaction to the increased violence within the scene and as an extension of the personal politics espoused by [[Ian MacKaye]] of [[Minor Threat]], who had turned the focus of the music from the community back towards the individual.<ref name="Greenwald, 12">{{cite book|last =Greenwald|first =Andy|authorlink =Andy Greenwald|title =[[Nothing Feels Good: Punk Rock, Teenagers, and Emo]]|publisher =[[St. Martin's Griffin]]|date =2003|location =[[New York City|New York]]|isbn =0-312-30863-9|page=9â11}}</ref><ref name="Blush, 157">{{cite book|last = Blush|first = Steven|authorlink = Steven Blush|title = [[American Hardcore: A Tribal History]]|publisher = [[Feral House]]|date = 2001|location = [[New York City|New York]]|isbn = 0-922925-71-7|page=157}}</ref> Minor Threat fan [[Guy Picciotto]] formed [[Rites of Spring]] in 1984, breaking free of hardcore's self-imposed boundaries in favor of melodic guitars, varied rhythms, and deeply personal, impassioned lyrics.<ref>Greenwald, p. 12.</ref> Many of the band's themes would become familiar tropes in later generations of emo music, including nostalgia, romantic bitterness, and poetic desperation.<ref>Greenwald, pp. 12â13.</ref> Their performances became public emotional purges where audience members would sometimes weep.<ref>Greenwald, p. 13.</ref> MacKaye became a huge Rites of Spring fan, recording their only album and serving as their roadie on tour, and soon formed a new band of his own called [[Embrace (American band)|Embrace]] which explored similar themes of self-searching and emotional release.<ref name="Greenwald, 14">Greenwald, p. 14.</ref> Similar bands soon followed in connection with the "Revolution Summer" of 1985, a deliberate attempt by members of the Washington, D.C. scene to break from the rigid constraints of hardcore in favor of a renewed spirit of creativity.<ref name="Blush, 157"/> Bands such as [[Gray Matter (band)|Gray Matter]], [[Beefeater (band)|Beefeater]], [[Fire Party]], [[Dag Nasty]], Lunchmeat, and Kingface were connected to this movement.<ref name="Blush, 157"/><ref name="Greenwald, 14"/>
 
The exact origins of the term "emo" are uncertain, but date back to at least 1985. According to [[Andy Greenwald]], author of ''[[Nothing Feels Good: Punk Rock, Teenagers, and Emo]]'', "The origins of the term 'emo' are shrouded in mystery [...] but it first came into common practice in 1985. If Minor Threat was hardcore, then Rites of Spring, with its altered focus, was emotional hardcore or emocore."<ref name="Greenwald, 14"/> [[Michael Azerrad]], author of ''[[Our Band Could Be Your Life]]'', also traces the word's origins to this time:
The exact origins of the term "emo" are uncertain, but date back to at least 1985. According to [[Andy Greenwald]], author of ''[[Nothing Feels Good: Punk Rock, Teenagers, and Emo]]'', "The origins of the term 'emo' are shrouded in mystery [...] but it first came into common practice in 1985. If Minor Threat was hardcore, then Rites of Spring, with its altered focus, was emotional hardcore or emocore."<ref name="Greenwald, 14"/> [[Michael Azerrad]], author of ''[[Our Band Could Be Your Life]]'', also traces the word's origins to this time:
Line 52: Line 52:
In the wake of the 1991 success of [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]]'s ''[[Nevermind]]'', underground music and subcultures in the United States became big business. New distribution networks emerged, touring routes were codified, and regional and independent acts were able to access the national stage.<ref name="Greenwald, 19"/> Teenagers across the country declared themselves fans of independent music, and being punk became mainstream.<ref name="Greenwald, 19"/> In this new musical climate, the aesthetics of emo expanded into the mainstream and altered the way the music was perceived: "Punk rock no-nos like the [[cult of personality]] and artistic abstraction suddenly become ''[[de rigueur]]''", says Greenwald. "If one definition of emo has always been music that felt like a secret, Jawbreaker and Sunny Day Real Estate were cast in the rolls of the biggest gossips of all, reigning as the largest influences on every emo band that came after them."<ref name="Greenwald, 20">Greenwald, p. 20.</ref>
In the wake of the 1991 success of [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]]'s ''[[Nevermind]]'', underground music and subcultures in the United States became big business. New distribution networks emerged, touring routes were codified, and regional and independent acts were able to access the national stage.<ref name="Greenwald, 19"/> Teenagers across the country declared themselves fans of independent music, and being punk became mainstream.<ref name="Greenwald, 19"/> In this new musical climate, the aesthetics of emo expanded into the mainstream and altered the way the music was perceived: "Punk rock no-nos like the [[cult of personality]] and artistic abstraction suddenly become ''[[de rigueur]]''", says Greenwald. "If one definition of emo has always been music that felt like a secret, Jawbreaker and Sunny Day Real Estate were cast in the rolls of the biggest gossips of all, reigning as the largest influences on every emo band that came after them."<ref name="Greenwald, 20">Greenwald, p. 20.</ref>
â
{{Listen
+
Jawbreaker has been referred to as "the [[Rosetta Stone]] of contemporary emo".<ref name="Greenwald, 20"/> Emerging from the [[San Francisco]] punk rock scene of the late 1980s and early 1990s, their songwriting combined the heft of hardcore with [[pop punk]] sensibilities and the tortured artistry of mid-1980s emocore.<ref name="Greenwald, 20"/> Singer/guitarist [[Blake Schwarzenbach]] focused his lyrics on topics that were personal, immediate, and lived, often lifting them directly from his journal.<ref>Greenwald, p. 21.</ref> Though they were often obscure and cloaked in [[metaphor]]s, their specificity to Schwarzenbach's own concerns gave the words a bitterness and frustration that made them universal and magnetic to audiences.<ref name="Greenwald, 21-22">Greenwald, pp. 21â22.</ref> Schwarzenbach became emo's first idol as listeners related to the singer more than the songs themselves.<ref name="Greenwald, 21-22"/> Jawbreaker's 1994 album ''[[24 Hour Revenge Therapy]]'' became their most-loved amongst fans and is a touchstone of mid-1990s emo.<ref>Greenwald, pp. 24â25. "''24 Hour Revenge Therapy'' is arguably Jawbreaker's best album, but it is also far and away its most loved".</ref> The band signed to major label [[Geffen Records]] and toured with Nirvana and [[Green Day]], but their 1995 album ''[[Dear You]]'' sold poorly and they broke up soon after, with Schwarzenbach later forming [[Jets to Brazil]].<ref>Greenwald, pp. 25â26.</ref> Their influence lived on, however, through later successful emo and pop punk bands openly indebted to Jawbreaker's sound.<ref>Greenwald, p. 26.</ref>
â
|filename = Jawbreaker - Kiss the Bottle.ogg
  â
|title = "Kiss the Bottle" by Jawbreaker
  â
|description = {{" '}}Kiss the Bottle,' more than any other song, captures the sensitive boy machismo that drew (and continues to draw) male listeners to the altar of Schwarzenbach."<ref>Greenwald, p. 23.</ref>
  â
}}Jawbreaker has been referred to as "the [[Rosetta Stone]] of contemporary emo".<ref name="Greenwald, 20"/> Emerging from the [[San Francisco]] punk rock scene of the late 1980s and early 1990s, their songwriting combined the heft of hardcore with [[pop punk]] sensibilities and the tortured artistry of mid-1980s emocore.<ref name="Greenwald, 20"/> Singer/guitarist [[Blake Schwarzenbach]] focused his lyrics on topics that were personal, immediate, and lived, often lifting them directly from his journal.<ref>Greenwald, p. 21.</ref> Though they were often obscure and cloaked in [[metaphor]]s, their specificity to Schwarzenbach's own concerns gave the words a bitterness and frustration that made them universal and magnetic to audiences.<ref name="Greenwald, 21-22">Greenwald, pp. 21â22.</ref> Schwarzenbach became emo's first idol as listeners related to the singer more than the songs themselves.<ref name="Greenwald, 21-22"/> Jawbreaker's 1994 album ''[[24 Hour Revenge Therapy]]'' became their most-loved amongst fans and is a touchstone of mid-1990s emo.<ref>Greenwald, pp. 24â25. "''24 Hour Revenge Therapy'' is arguably Jawbreaker's best album, but it is also far and away its most loved".</ref> The band signed to major label [[Geffen Records]] and toured with Nirvana and [[Green Day]], but their 1995 album ''[[Dear You]]'' sold poorly and they broke up soon after, with Schwarzenbach later forming [[Jets to Brazil]].<ref>Greenwald, pp. 25â26.</ref> Their influence lived on, however, through later successful emo and pop punk bands openly indebted to Jawbreaker's sound.<ref>Greenwald, p. 26.</ref>
  â
{{Listen
+
Sunny Day Real Estate formed in [[Seattle]] during the height of the early-1990s [[grunge]] boom.<ref name="Greenwald, 28">Greenwald, p. 28.</ref> In contrast to Jawbreaker, its members were accomplished musicians with high-quality gear, lofty musical ambitions, intricate songwriting, and a sweeping, epic sound.<ref name="Greenwald, 28"/> Frontman [[Jeremy Enigk]] sang desperately, in a [[falsetto]] register, about losing himself and subsuming himself in something greater, often using haphazard lyrics and made-up words.<ref>Greenwald, pp. 28â29.</ref> The band's debut album ''[[Diary (album)|Diary]]'' (1994) was over-the-top and romantic, and the [[music video]] for "Seven" received airplay on [[MTV]].<ref>Greenwald, p. 30.</ref> The band's ambitious sound challenged other bands to reach further with their own music in sentiment, instrumentation, and metaphor, and represented a generational shift between grunge and emo.<ref name="Greenwald, 29-31">Greenwald, pp. 29â31.</ref> Other emo-leaning punk bands soon followed suit, and the word "emo" began to shift from being vague and undefined to referring to a specific type of emotionally overbearing music that was romantic but distanced from the political nature of punk rock.<ref>Greenwald, pp. 31â32.</ref> Sunny Day Real Estate fell apart after ''Diary'', as Enigk became a [[Born again (Christianity)|born-again Christian]] and launched a solo career while the other members drifted into new projects such as the [[Foo Fighters]]. They released three more albums through a series of breakups and occasional reunions, but are remembered primarily for the promise of their debut and the shift it engendered in the tastes of underground rock fans.<ref>Greenwald, p. 32. ""[I]n many ways Sunny Day's brilliance ''was'' its zeitgeist-seizing debut, physically forcing a regime change in the hearts and minds of fans of underground rock."</ref>
â
|filename = Sunny Day Real Estate - Seven.ogg
  â
|title = "Seven" by Sunny Day Real Estate
  â
|description = [[Sunny Day Real Estate]]'s epic sound challenged other bands to reach further with their own music. "Seven" helped bring emo towards the mainstream when it received airplay on [[MTV]].}}Sunny Day Real Estate formed in [[Seattle]] during the height of the early-1990s [[grunge]] boom.<ref name="Greenwald, 28">Greenwald, p. 28.</ref> In contrast to Jawbreaker, its members were accomplished musicians with high-quality gear, lofty musical ambitions, intricate songwriting, and a sweeping, epic sound.<ref name="Greenwald, 28"/> Frontman [[Jeremy Enigk]] sang desperately, in a [[falsetto]] register, about losing himself and subsuming himself in something greater, often using haphazard lyrics and made-up words.<ref>Greenwald, pp. 28â29.</ref> The band's debut album ''[[Diary (album)|Diary]]'' (1994) was over-the-top and romantic, and the [[music video]] for "Seven" received airplay on [[MTV]].<ref>Greenwald, p. 30.</ref> The band's ambitious sound challenged other bands to reach further with their own music in sentiment, instrumentation, and metaphor, and represented a generational shift between grunge and emo.<ref name="Greenwald, 29-31">Greenwald, pp. 29â31.</ref> Other emo-leaning punk bands soon followed suit, and the word "emo" began to shift from being vague and undefined to referring to a specific type of emotionally overbearing music that was romantic but distanced from the political nature of punk rock.<ref>Greenwald, pp. 31â32.</ref> Sunny Day Real Estate fell apart after ''Diary'', as Enigk became a [[Born again (Christianity)|born-again Christian]] and launched a solo career while the other members drifted into new projects such as the [[Foo Fighters]]. They released three more albums through a series of breakups and occasional reunions, but are remembered primarily for the promise of their debut and the shift it engendered in the tastes of underground rock fans.<ref>Greenwald, p. 32. ""[I]n many ways Sunny Day's brilliance ''was'' its zeitgeist-seizing debut, physically forcing a regime change in the hearts and minds of fans of underground rock."</ref>
 
===Underground popularity: mid 1990s===
===Underground popularity: mid 1990s===
In the mid-1990s the American [[punk rock|punk]] and [[indie rock]] movements, which had been largely underground since the early 1980s, became part of mainstream culture. After [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]]'s success, major record labels capitalized on the popularity of [[alternative rock]] and other underground music by signing numerous independent bands and spending large amounts of capital promoting them.<ref name="Greenwald, 33">Greenwald, p. 33.</ref> In 1994, the same year that Jawbreaker's ''24 Hour Revenge Therapy'' and Sunny Day Real Estate's ''Diary'' were released, [[pop punk]] acts [[Green Day]] and [[The Offspring]] had [[RIAA certification#List of certifications|mutiplatinum]] successes with their respective albums ''[[Dookie]]'' and ''[[Smash (album)|Smash]]''. In the wake of the underground going mainstream, over the next several years emo as a genre retreated, reformed, and morphed into a national subculture, then eventually something more.<ref name="Greenwald, 33"/> Drawing inspiration from bands like Jawbreaker, [[Drive Like Jehu]], and [[Fugazi]], the new sound of emo was a mixture of [[hardcore punk|hardcore]]'s passion and indie rock's intelligence, bearing the anthemic power of punk rock and its [[Do it yourself|do-it-yourself]] work ethic but with smoother songs, sloppier melodies, and yearning vocals.<ref name="Greenwald, 34-35">Greenwald, pp. 34â35.</ref> Many of the new emo bands originated from the [[Midwestern United States|Midwestern]] and [[Central United States]], such as [[Braid (band)|Braid]] from [[Champaign, Illinois|Champaign]]-[[Urbana, Illinois]], [[Christie Front Drive]] from [[Denver]], [[Colorado]], [[Mineral (band)|Mineral]] from [[Austin, Texas]], [[Jimmy Eat World]] from [[Mesa, Arizona]], [[The Get Up Kids]] from [[Kansas City, Missouri]], and [[The Promise Ring]] from [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]].<ref>Greenwald, p. 34.</ref> According to [[Andy Greenwald]], "This was the period when emo earned many, if not all, of the stereotypes that have lasted to this day: boy-driven, glasses-wearing, overly sensitive, overly brainy, chiming-guitar-driven college music."<ref name="Greenwald, 34-35" />
In the mid-1990s the American [[punk rock|punk]] and [[indie rock]] movements, which had been largely underground since the early 1980s, became part of mainstream culture. After [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]]'s success, major record labels capitalized on the popularity of [[alternative rock]] and other underground music by signing numerous independent bands and spending large amounts of capital promoting them.<ref name="Greenwald, 33">Greenwald, p. 33.</ref> In 1994, the same year that Jawbreaker's ''24 Hour Revenge Therapy'' and Sunny Day Real Estate's ''Diary'' were released, [[pop punk]] acts [[Green Day]] and [[The Offspring]] had [[RIAA certification#List of certifications|mutiplatinum]] successes with their respective albums ''[[Dookie]]'' and ''[[Smash (album)|Smash]]''. In the wake of the underground going mainstream, over the next several years emo as a genre retreated, reformed, and morphed into a national subculture, then eventually something more.<ref name="Greenwald, 33"/> Drawing inspiration from bands like Jawbreaker, [[Drive Like Jehu]], and [[Fugazi]], the new sound of emo was a mixture of [[hardcore punk|hardcore]]'s passion and indie rock's intelligence, bearing the anthemic power of punk rock and its [[Do it yourself|do-it-yourself]] work ethic but with smoother songs, sloppier melodies, and yearning vocals.<ref name="Greenwald, 34-35">Greenwald, pp. 34â35.</ref> Many of the new emo bands originated from the [[Midwestern United States|Midwestern]] and [[Central United States]], such as [[Braid (band)|Braid]] from [[Champaign, Illinois|Champaign]]-[[Urbana, Illinois]], [[Christie Front Drive]] from [[Denver]], [[Colorado]], [[Mineral (band)|Mineral]] from [[Austin, Texas]], [[Jimmy Eat World]] from [[Mesa, Arizona]], [[The Get Up Kids]] from [[Kansas City, Missouri]], and [[The Promise Ring]] from [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]].<ref>Greenwald, p. 34.</ref> According to [[Andy Greenwald]], "This was the period when emo earned many, if not all, of the stereotypes that have lasted to this day: boy-driven, glasses-wearing, overly sensitive, overly brainy, chiming-guitar-driven college music."<ref name="Greenwald, 34-35" />
â
{{Listen
+
On the east coast, [[New York City]]-based [[Texas Is the Reason]] bridged the gap between indie rock and emo in their brief three-year lifespan by melding the melodies of Sunny Day Real Estate to churning punk musicianship and singing directly to the listener.<ref name="Greenwald, 38-39">Greenwald, pp. 38â39.</ref> In [[New Jersey]], [[Lifetime (band)|Lifetime]] gained a reputation as a [[melodic hardcore]] act, playing shows in fans' basements.<ref name="Greenwald, 121-122">Greenwald, pp. 121â122.</ref> Their 1995 album ''[[Hello Bastards]]'' on rising independent label [[Jade Tree Records]] fused hardcore with emo's tunefulness, turning its back on cynicism and irony in favor of love songs.<ref name="Greenwald, 121-122"/> The album sold tens of thousands of copies<ref name="Greenwald, 122">Greenwald, p. 122.</ref> and the band inspired a number of later New Jersey and [[Long Island]] emo acts such as [[Brand New]], [[Glassjaw]], [[Midtown (band)|Midtown]],<ref name="Rashbaum">{{cite web|last = Rashbaum|first = Alyssa|title = A Lifetime of Rock|url = http://www.spin.com/articles/lifetime-rock|publisher = ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]''|date = 2006-03-24|accessdate = 2009-03-28}}</ref> [[The Movielife]], [[My Chemical Romance]],<ref name="Rashbaum"/> [[Saves the Day]],<ref name="Rashbaum"/><ref name="Greenwald, 80">Greenwald, p. 80.</ref> [[Senses Fail]],<ref name="Rashbaum"/> [[Taking Back Sunday]],<ref name="Greenwald, 122">Greenwald, p. 122.</ref><ref name="Rashbaum"/> and [[Thursday (band)|Thursday]].<ref name="Rashbaum"/><ref name="Greenwald, 152">Greenwald, p. 152.</ref>
â
|filename = Texas Is the Reason - If It's Here When We Get Back It's Ours.ogg
  â
|title = "If It's Here When We Get Back It's Ours" by Texas Is the Reason
  â
|description = [[Texas Is the Reason]] bridged [[indie rock]] and emo by blending melody with punk musicianship and singing directly to the listener.
  â
|filename2 = Lifetime - Knives, Bats, New Tats.ogg
  â
|title2 = "Knives, Bats, New Tats" by Lifetime
  â
|description2 = [[Lifetime (band)|Lifetime]]'s brand of [[melodic hardcore]] with introspective lyrics inspired numerous later [[New Jersey]] and [[Long Island]] emo bands.
  â
}}On the east coast, [[New York City]]-based [[Texas Is the Reason]] bridged the gap between indie rock and emo in their brief three-year lifespan by melding the melodies of Sunny Day Real Estate to churning punk musicianship and singing directly to the listener.<ref name="Greenwald, 38-39">Greenwald, pp. 38â39.</ref> In [[New Jersey]], [[Lifetime (band)|Lifetime]] gained a reputation as a [[melodic hardcore]] act, playing shows in fans' basements.<ref name="Greenwald, 121-122">Greenwald, pp. 121â122.</ref> Their 1995 album ''[[Hello Bastards]]'' on rising independent label [[Jade Tree Records]] fused hardcore with emo's tunefulness, turning its back on cynicism and irony in favor of love songs.<ref name="Greenwald, 121-122"/> The album sold tens of thousands of copies<ref name="Greenwald, 122">Greenwald, p. 122.</ref> and the band inspired a number of later New Jersey and [[Long Island]] emo acts such as [[Brand New]], [[Glassjaw]], [[Midtown (band)|Midtown]],<ref name="Rashbaum">{{cite web|last = Rashbaum|first = Alyssa|title = A Lifetime of Rock|url = http://www.spin.com/articles/lifetime-rock|publisher = ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]''|date = 2006-03-24|accessdate = 2009-03-28}}</ref> [[The Movielife]], [[My Chemical Romance]],<ref name="Rashbaum"/> [[Saves the Day]],<ref name="Rashbaum"/><ref name="Greenwald, 80">Greenwald, p. 80.</ref> [[Senses Fail]],<ref name="Rashbaum"/> [[Taking Back Sunday]],<ref name="Greenwald, 122">Greenwald, p. 122.</ref><ref name="Rashbaum"/> and [[Thursday (band)|Thursday]].<ref name="Rashbaum"/><ref name="Greenwald, 152">Greenwald, p. 152.</ref>
 
The Promise Ring were one of the premier bands of the new emo style. Their music took a slower, smoother, pop punk approach to hardcore riffs, blending them with singer [[Davey von Bohlen]]'s goofy, picturesque lyrics delivered with a froggy croon and pronounced [[lisp]], and they played shows in basements and [[Veterans of Foreign Wars|VFW]] halls<ref>Greenwald, pp. 35â36.</ref> Jade Tree released their debut ''[[30Â° Everywhere]]'' in 1996 and it sold tens of thousands of copies, a blockbuster by independent standards.<ref>Greenwald, p. 36.</ref> Greenwald describes the effect of the album as "like being hit in the head with cotton candy."<ref>Greenwald, p. 37.</ref> Other bands such as [[Karate (band)|Karate]], [[The Van Pelt]], [[Joan of Arc (band)|Joan of Arc]], and The Shyness Clinic incorporated elements of [[post-rock]] and [[noise rock]] into the emo sound.<ref name="Greenwald, 40">Greenwald, p. 40.</ref> The common lyrical thread between these bands was "applying big questions to small scenarios."<ref name="Greenwald, 40"/>
The Promise Ring were one of the premier bands of the new emo style. Their music took a slower, smoother, pop punk approach to hardcore riffs, blending them with singer [[Davey von Bohlen]]'s goofy, picturesque lyrics delivered with a froggy croon and pronounced [[lisp]], and they played shows in basements and [[Veterans of Foreign Wars|VFW]] halls<ref>Greenwald, pp. 35â36.</ref> Jade Tree released their debut ''[[30Â° Everywhere]]'' in 1996 and it sold tens of thousands of copies, a blockbuster by independent standards.<ref>Greenwald, p. 36.</ref> Greenwald describes the effect of the album as "like being hit in the head with cotton candy."<ref>Greenwald, p. 37.</ref> Other bands such as [[Karate (band)|Karate]], [[The Van Pelt]], [[Joan of Arc (band)|Joan of Arc]], and The Shyness Clinic incorporated elements of [[post-rock]] and [[noise rock]] into the emo sound.<ref name="Greenwald, 40">Greenwald, p. 40.</ref> The common lyrical thread between these bands was "applying big questions to small scenarios."<ref name="Greenwald, 40"/>
â
{{Listen
+
A cornerstone of mid-1990s emo was [[Weezer]]'s 1996 album ''[[Pinkerton (album)|Pinkerton]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last = Edwards|first = Gavin|title = Review: ''Pinkerton''|url = http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/weezer/albums/album/301487/review/6635729/pinkerton|publisher = ''[[Rolling Stone]]''|date = 2001-12-09|accessdate = 2009-03-23}}</ref> Following the success of their [[Weezer (1994 album)|mutiplatinum debut]], ''Pinkerton'' turned from their [[power pop]] sound to a much darker, more abrasive character.<ref>{{cite web|last = Erlewine| first = Stephen|url = http://allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=10:3xfexqlhld6e~T0|title = Allmusic: Pinkerton: Overview|publisher = [[Allmusic]]|accessdate = 2007-09-21}}</ref><ref name="Greenwald, 50">Greenwald, p. 50.</ref> Frontman [[Rivers Cuomo]]'s songs were obsessed with messy, manipulative sex and his own insecurities of dealing with celebrity.<ref name="Greenwald, 50"/> A critical and commercial failure,<ref name="Greenwald, 50"/><ref>{{cite book|last =Luerssen|first = John D.|title =Rivers' Edge: The Weezer Story|publisher =[[ECW Press]]|date =2004|location =[[Toronto]]|isbn =1-55022-619-3|page =206}}</ref> it was ranked by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' as the second-worst album of the year.<ref>Luerssen, p. 137.</ref> Cuomo retreated from the public eye,<ref name="Greenwald, 50"/> later referring to the album as "hideous" and "a hugely painful mistake".<ref>Luerssen, p. 348.</ref> However, ''Pinkerton'' found enduring appeal with teenagers just discovering [[alternative rock]], who were drawn to its confessional lyrics and themes of rejection and came to believe that it was directed at them.<ref name="Greenwald, 51">Greenwald, p. 51.</ref> Sales grew steadily as word of the album passed between fans, over online messageboards, and via [[Napster]].<ref name="Greenwald, 51"/> "Although no one was paying attention", says Greenwald, "perhaps ''because'' no one was paying attentionâ''Pinkerton'' became the most important emo album of the decade."<ref name="Greenwald, 51"/> When Weezer returned in 2000, however, they did so with a decidedly [[pop music|pop]] sound. Cuomo refused to play songs from ''Pinkerton'', dismissing it as "ugly" and "embarrassing".<ref>Greenwald, p. 52.</ref> Nevertheless, the album held its appeal and eventually achieved both high sales and critical praise, and is noted for introducing emo to larger and more mainstream audiences.<ref>{{cite web|last = Montgomery|first = James|title = The Argument: Weezer Are the Most Important Band of the Last 10 Years|url = http://www.mtv.com/bands/w/weezer/news_feature_102504/|publisher = [[MTV]]|date = 2004-10-25|accessdate = 2009-03-23}}</ref>
â
|filename = Weezer - El Scorcho.ogg
  â
|title = "El Scorcho" by Weezer
  â
|description = ''[[Pinkerton (album)|Pinkerton]]''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s abrasive sound and confessional lyrics led to critical and commercial failure in the short term, but in retrospect it is regarded as the most important emo album of the 1990s.}}A cornerstone of mid-1990s emo was [[Weezer]]'s 1996 album ''[[Pinkerton (album)|Pinkerton]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last = Edwards|first = Gavin|title = Review: ''Pinkerton''|url = http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/weezer/albums/album/301487/review/6635729/pinkerton|publisher = ''[[Rolling Stone]]''|date = 2001-12-09|accessdate = 2009-03-23}}</ref> Following the success of their [[Weezer (1994 album)|mutiplatinum debut]], ''Pinkerton'' turned from their [[power pop]] sound to a much darker, more abrasive character.<ref>{{cite web|last = Erlewine| first = Stephen|url = http://allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=10:3xfexqlhld6e~T0|title = Allmusic: Pinkerton: Overview|publisher = [[Allmusic]]|accessdate = 2007-09-21}}</ref><ref name="Greenwald, 50">Greenwald, p. 50.</ref> Frontman [[Rivers Cuomo]]'s songs were obsessed with messy, manipulative sex and his own insecurities of dealing with celebrity.<ref name="Greenwald, 50"/> A critical and commercial failure,<ref name="Greenwald, 50"/><ref>{{cite book|last =Luerssen|first = John D.|title =Rivers' Edge: The Weezer Story|publisher =[[ECW Press]]|date =2004|location =[[Toronto]]|isbn =1-55022-619-3|page =206}}</ref> it was ranked by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' as the second-worst album of the year.<ref>Luerssen, p. 137.</ref> Cuomo retreated from the public eye,<ref name="Greenwald, 50"/> later referring to the album as "hideous" and "a hugely painful mistake".<ref>Luerssen, p. 348.</ref> However, ''Pinkerton'' found enduring appeal with teenagers just discovering [[alternative rock]], who were drawn to its confessional lyrics and themes of rejection and came to believe that it was directed at them.<ref name="Greenwald, 51">Greenwald, p. 51.</ref> Sales grew steadily as word of the album passed between fans, over online messageboards, and via [[Napster]].<ref name="Greenwald, 51"/> "Although no one was paying attention", says Greenwald, "perhaps ''because'' no one was paying attentionâ''Pinkerton'' became the most important emo album of the decade."<ref name="Greenwald, 51"/> When Weezer returned in 2000, however, they did so with a decidedly [[pop music|pop]] sound. Cuomo refused to play songs from ''Pinkerton'', dismissing it as "ugly" and "embarrassing".<ref>Greenwald, p. 52.</ref> Nevertheless, the album held its appeal and eventually achieved both high sales and critical praise, and is noted for introducing emo to larger and more mainstream audiences.<ref>{{cite web|last = Montgomery|first = James|title = The Argument: Weezer Are the Most Important Band of the Last 10 Years|url = http://www.mtv.com/bands/w/weezer/news_feature_102504/|publisher = [[MTV]]|date = 2004-10-25|accessdate = 2009-03-23}}</ref>
 
{{Listen
{{Listen
Line 71: Line 71:
}}The emo aesthetic of the mid-1990s was embodied in Mineral, whose albums ''[[The Power of Failing]]'' (1997) and ''[[EndSerenading]]'' (1998) encapsulated the emo tropes of somber music accompanied by a shy narrator singing seriously about mundane problems.<ref name="Greenwald, 41">Greenwald, p. 41.</ref> Greenwald calls their song "If I Could" "the ultimate expression of mid-nineties emo. The song's short synopsisâshe is beautiful, I am weak, dumb, and shy; I am alone but am surprisingly poetic when left aloneâsums up everything that emo's adherents admired and its detractors detested."<ref name="Greenwald, 41"/> Another significant band of the era was Braid, whose 1998 album ''[[Frame and Canvas]]'' and [[A-side and B-side|B-side]] song "Forever Got Shorter" blurred the lines between band and listener, as the group was a mirror-image of its own audience in passion and sentiment and sang in the voice of their fans.<ref>Greenwald, pp. 46â48.</ref>
}}The emo aesthetic of the mid-1990s was embodied in Mineral, whose albums ''[[The Power of Failing]]'' (1997) and ''[[EndSerenading]]'' (1998) encapsulated the emo tropes of somber music accompanied by a shy narrator singing seriously about mundane problems.<ref name="Greenwald, 41">Greenwald, p. 41.</ref> Greenwald calls their song "If I Could" "the ultimate expression of mid-nineties emo. The song's short synopsisâshe is beautiful, I am weak, dumb, and shy; I am alone but am surprisingly poetic when left aloneâsums up everything that emo's adherents admired and its detractors detested."<ref name="Greenwald, 41"/> Another significant band of the era was Braid, whose 1998 album ''[[Frame and Canvas]]'' and [[A-side and B-side|B-side]] song "Forever Got Shorter" blurred the lines between band and listener, as the group was a mirror-image of its own audience in passion and sentiment and sang in the voice of their fans.<ref>Greenwald, pp. 46â48.</ref>
â
{{Listen
+
Though the emo style of the mid-1990s had thousands of young fans, it never broke into the national consciousness.<ref name="Greenwald, 42">Greenwald, p. 42.</ref> A few bands were offered contracts with major record labels, but most broke up before they could capitalize on the opportunity.<ref>Greenwald, pp. 45â46.</ref> Jimmy Eat World signed to [[Capitol Records]] in 1995 and built a following among the emo community with their album ''[[Static Prevails]]'', but did not break into the mainstream despite their major-label association as their music was mostly lost amongst the popular [[ska]] movement of the period.<ref>Greenwald, pp. 99â101.</ref> The Promise Ring were the most commercially successful emo band of the time, with sales of their 1997 album ''[[Nothing Feels Good]]'' topping out in the mid-five figures.<ref name="Greenwald, 42"/> Greenwald calls the album "the pinnacle of its generation of emo: a convergence of pop and punk, of resignation and celebration, of the lure of girlfriends and the pull of friends, bandmates, and the road."<ref name="Greenwald, 44">Greenwald, p. 44.</ref> He refers to mid-1990s emo as "the last subculture made of vinyl and paper instead of plastic and megabytes."<ref>Greenwald, 48.</ref>
â
|filename = The Promise Ring - Why Did We Ever Meet.ogg
  â
|title = "Why Did Ever We Meet" by The Promise Ring
  â
|description = [[The Promise Ring]]'s ''[[Nothing Feels Good]]'' was the most commercially successful emo album of the mid-1990s due to its effective blend of pop and punk.
  â
}}Though the emo style of the mid-1990s had thousands of young fans, it never broke into the national consciousness.<ref name="Greenwald, 42">Greenwald, p. 42.</ref> A few bands were offered contracts with major record labels, but most broke up before they could capitalize on the opportunity.<ref>Greenwald, pp. 45â46.</ref> Jimmy Eat World signed to [[Capitol Records]] in 1995 and built a following among the emo community with their album ''[[Static Prevails]]'', but did not break into the mainstream despite their major-label association as their music was mostly lost amongst the popular [[ska]] movement of the period.<ref>Greenwald, pp. 99â101.</ref> The Promise Ring were the most commercially successful emo band of the time, with sales of their 1997 album ''[[Nothing Feels Good]]'' topping out in the mid-five figures.<ref name="Greenwald, 42"/> Greenwald calls the album "the pinnacle of its generation of emo: a convergence of pop and punk, of resignation and celebration, of the lure of girlfriends and the pull of friends, bandmates, and the road."<ref name="Greenwald, 44">Greenwald, p. 44.</ref> He refers to mid-1990s emo as "the last subculture made of vinyl and paper instead of plastic and megabytes."<ref>Greenwald, 48.</ref>
 
===Independent success: late 1990s and early 2000s===
===Independent success: late 1990s and early 2000s===
Line 94: Line 94:
</blockquote>
</blockquote>
â
{{Listen
+
Independent label [[Vagrant Records]] was behind several successful emo acts of the late 1990s and early 2000s. [[The Get Up Kids]] had sold over 15,000 copies of their debut album ''[[Four Minute Mile]]'' (1997) before signing to Vagrant, who promoted the band aggressively and put them on tours opening for big-name acts like [[Green Day]] and [[Weezer]].<ref>Greenwald, pp. 77â78.</ref> Their 1999 album ''[[Something to Write Home About]]'' was an independent success, reaching #31 on [[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard'']]'s [[Top Heatseekers]] chart.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/esearch/chart_display.jsp?cfi=294&cfgn=Albums&cfn=Heatseekers&ci=3035794&cdi=7505634&cid=10%2F23%2F1999 |title=Heatseekers: Something to Write Home About|publisher=[[Billboard charts|''Billboard'' charts]] |accessdate=2009-03-25}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Vagrant signed and released albums by a number of other emo and emo-related acts over the next two years, including [[The Anniversary]], [[Reggie and the Full Effect]], [[The New Amsterdams]], [[Alkaline Trio]], [[Saves the Day]], [[Dashboard Confessional]], [[Hey Mercedes]], and [[Hot Rod Circuit]].<ref>Greenwald, p. 79.</ref> Saves the Day had built a large following on the east coast and sold almost 50,000 copies of their second album ''[[Through Being Cool]]'' (1999)<ref name="Greenwald, 80"/> before signing to Vagrant and releasing ''[[Stay What You Are]]'' (2001), which sold 15,000 copies in its first week,<ref name="Greenwald, 81">Greenwald, p. 81.</ref> reached #100 on the ''Billboard'' 200,<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/retrieve_chart_history.do?model.chartFormatGroupName=Albums&model.vnuArtistId=281258&model.vnuAlbumId=814700 |title=Artist Chart History - Saves the Day|publisher=[[Billboard charts|''Billboard'' charts]] |accessdate=2009-03-26}}</ref> and went on to sell over 200,000 copies.<ref name="Saves the Day Allmusic bio">{{cite web|last = Wilson|first = MacKenzie|url = http://www.allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=11:f9fwxqljldde~T1 |title=Saves the Day Biography|publisher = [[Allmusic]]|accessdate = 2009-03-26}}</ref> In the summer of 2001 Vagrant organized a national tour featuring every band on the label, sponsored by corporations such as [[Microsoft]] and [[The Coca-Cola Company|Coca-Cola]]. This populist approach and the use of the [[internet]] as a marketing tool helped Vagrant become one of the country's most successful independent labels and also helped to popularize the term "emo".<ref>Greenwald, pp. 81â88.</ref> According Greenwald, "More than any other event, it was Vagrant America that defined emo to massesâmainly because it had the gumption to hit the road and bring it to ''them''."<ref name="Greenwald, 81"/>
â
|filename = The Get Up Kids - Action & Action.ogg
  â
|title = "Action & Action" by The Get Up Kids
  â
|description = [[The Get Up Kids]]' ''[[Something to Write Home About]]'' helped [[Vagrant Records]] expand into a much larger label and sign numerous other emo acts.
  â
}}Independent label [[Vagrant Records]] was behind several successful emo acts of the late 1990s and early 2000s. [[The Get Up Kids]] had sold over 15,000 copies of their debut album ''[[Four Minute Mile]]'' (1997) before signing to Vagrant, who promoted the band aggressively and put them on tours opening for big-name acts like [[Green Day]] and [[Weezer]].<ref>Greenwald, pp. 77â78.</ref> Their 1999 album ''[[Something to Write Home About]]'' was an independent success, reaching #31 on [[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard'']]'s [[Top Heatseekers]] chart.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/esearch/chart_display.jsp?cfi=294&cfgn=Albums&cfn=Heatseekers&ci=3035794&cdi=7505634&cid=10%2F23%2F1999 |title=Heatseekers: Something to Write Home About|publisher=[[Billboard charts|''Billboard'' charts]] |accessdate=2009-03-25}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Vagrant signed and released albums by a number of other emo and emo-related acts over the next two years, including [[The Anniversary]], [[Reggie and the Full Effect]], [[The New Amsterdams]], [[Alkaline Trio]], [[Saves the Day]], [[Dashboard Confessional]], [[Hey Mercedes]], and [[Hot Rod Circuit]].<ref>Greenwald, p. 79.</ref> Saves the Day had built a large following on the east coast and sold almost 50,000 copies of their second album ''[[Through Being Cool]]'' (1999)<ref name="Greenwald, 80"/> before signing to Vagrant and releasing ''[[Stay What You Are]]'' (2001), which sold 15,000 copies in its first week,<ref name="Greenwald, 81">Greenwald, p. 81.</ref> reached #100 on the ''Billboard'' 200,<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/retrieve_chart_history.do?model.chartFormatGroupName=Albums&model.vnuArtistId=281258&model.vnuAlbumId=814700 |title=Artist Chart History - Saves the Day|publisher=[[Billboard charts|''Billboard'' charts]] |accessdate=2009-03-26}}</ref> and went on to sell over 200,000 copies.<ref name="Saves the Day Allmusic bio">{{cite web|last = Wilson|first = MacKenzie|url = http://www.allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=11:f9fwxqljldde~T1 |title=Saves the Day Biography|publisher = [[Allmusic]]|accessdate = 2009-03-26}}</ref> In the summer of 2001 Vagrant organized a national tour featuring every band on the label, sponsored by corporations such as [[Microsoft]] and [[The Coca-Cola Company|Coca-Cola]]. This populist approach and the use of the [[internet]] as a marketing tool helped Vagrant become one of the country's most successful independent labels and also helped to popularize the term "emo".<ref>Greenwald, pp. 81â88.</ref> According Greenwald, "More than any other event, it was Vagrant America that defined emo to massesâmainly because it had the gumption to hit the road and bring it to ''them''."<ref name="Greenwald, 81"/>
